dialogue.text: Because I don't like your ugly language. I heard enough of it in school!  Now speak Czech or English.  And don't fool around anymore.  You almost got us thrown out!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Look.  New videocameras.  Color viewfinder.  Image stabilization. Solarization.  Night vision.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: We have no money.  Come on.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Turn that off!  Get the bags.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Why should I carry your bag?  I am not a dog.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: For five years I paid for your stupidness - you'll carry my bag for the rest of my life if I say so.  Unless you refuse, Oleg.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Smell like chemicals...for smoking drugs.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Turn that fucking thing off!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: I'm not filming.  I'm watching Milos die.  It's just like a move but realer.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Speak English!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: You said speak Czech!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: How you erase this?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: I'll do it.  Don't hurt my camera!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Whore?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: I'm homesick.  You have Eastern European girl?  A Czech girl?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Get in the bathroom!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Whatever we do - we fuck her, right?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Oleg, get in bathroom, stay there and shut up!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Gotta light the scene better.  Now it's more moody... like a scene from THE THIRD MAN.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Does it hurt?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Oh, shit.  I hate looking at that!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Don't want to film this?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: The video of Milos and Tamina - I told you to erase it.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: I did.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: And the whore's murder?  You didn't erase that either, did you?  Don't lie, I won't be angry.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Put the camera down, Oleg.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: What is that?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: What does it look like?  It's an address book!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Let me get a shot of it.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Sit down!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: This way.  Hold it this way.  Good.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: No.  We are insane.  Who else but crazy men would film their murders?  So we kill someone famous and if we are caught, we are sent to mental hospital. But what good is money there?  Because once in hospital I say I not crazy. Just pretended to be acquitted.  We see psychiatrists.  They must certify we are sane and because of your - what is law called?  Oh - I got it.  Because of your Double Jeopardy law, we can't be tried for same crime twice.  We come out free, rich and famous!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Good idea!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Okay.  He has nothing to say.  Start the camera!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Cut!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: You are success story?  I am success story!  Why do you say I and not we?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Oleg, don't be paranoid.  You got a hundred-fifty thousand dollars, didn't you?  I gave you half of what they gave me.  Look - here we are!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: In movie they make of us, who do you think would act me?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: The one who got caught in the bathroom.  George Michael.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Shut up.  Look!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: This is my project.  I say 'action.'  I am the director!  You are the talent. You wait for me to say 'action.'  And 'action!'

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Bad last moment - I cut it out.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: I told you to cut that out before we handed in the tape!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Be quiet.  Watch.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Why did you leave that stuff in about you being the director?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Because I am the director.  Don't you realize, if it wasn't for my film, for my talent, my idea to do this - no way would we be sitting here right now.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Your idea?  I thought it was my idea.

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: I'm serious...this - this is a great American film.  Full of violence and sex.  And I want my credit.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Credit?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Yes.  Before we hand in the next video - I put titles on it and my credit is going to read - Directed by Oleg Razgul.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Yes.  But there's only one problem - you want credit but the problem is - I don't share credit.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: You got that?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: No, I don't get that!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: You think you are a director?  You are a fucking little, small Russian piece of shit.  And I hate you.  I fucking hate you.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Traitor!!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: No.  You are the traitor.  You are murderer.  I am director.  Action!

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: Emil???!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Surprise!  Surprise!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Your sister said she didn't know where you were so you shouldn't write to her with return address if you're hiding.

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: Did you hurt her?

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: You know me...I never hurt anybody. Where's the money?

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: Take your eyes off her, Oleg!  Look.  It wasn't my fault you two were caught.  It's his fault.  Trying to get the bank clerk's phone number?!  I wasn't going to wait!!!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Milos.  Get my money!

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: We spent it!

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: Ha. Ha.

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: Look at the way we live.  I'm a plumber. You think I'd be working if I had money?!

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: I can get you a job.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: A job?

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: Yes, the money is good.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: As a plumber?!

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: It's easy to learn.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: A job??  As a plumber???  You think I come to America to work!

dialogue.speaker: MILOS
dialogue.text: We started over, you can too.

dialogue.speaker: EMIL
dialogue.text: You spent all the money while I was in prison?  Now you tell me to get a job fixing toilets?!?

dialogue.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogue.text: Robert...?

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: What are you doing here?

dialogue.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogue.text: You've got a call.

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: I can't talk to anybody right now, can't you see I'm busy!  I can't talk business.  Hang up.  Have a drink.  Get her a whiskey.

dialogue.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogue.text: Trust me, you'll want to take this call.

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: Viewer discretion advised!

dialogue.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogue.text: You want the tape?  There it is!

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: Isn't he a little moody?

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: Of course he's moody.  He thinks he's in love.

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: In love?  With who?

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: Paulie, you've got kids, right?

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: And you, you'll pay for what you did!

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: This footage will work in your favor. When the jury sees this - no matter what Cutler tries, they'll convict him.

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: You outta be ashamed.  Ashamed of yourself.

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: If I didn't put it on somebody else would!  I was his friend!

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: Don't give me that fucking shit.

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogue.text: What do you mean you know?  He told you he was gonna propose to me?

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: Well, he...

dialogue.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogue.text: I want to hear everything he said.

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: I'm trying to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogue.text: Alright.  Go ahead.

dialogue.speaker: HAWKINS
dialogue.text: That morning.  He was talking to me and Leon about marriage.

dialogue.speaker: NICOLETTE
dialogue.text: Oh my G-d.  We were having lunch here. He started making overtures - talking about little shoes next to his in his closet but I got a call to anchor - and I walked out on him.  I walked out on him when he was trying to ask me to marry him!!

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Yes...he's my friend.

dialogue.speaker: IMMIGRATION OFFICER
dialogue.text: Okay.  You're a Czech national and you're a Russian national.  How do you know one another?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: I speak English.

dialogue.speaker: IMMIGRATION OFFICER
dialogue.text: Then answer my questions.  Where were you planning to stay during the two weeks that you're here?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: New York.

dialogue.speaker: IMMIGRATION OFFICER
dialogue.text: Yes, we're in New York now.  But where are you planning to stay in New York?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: A cheap hotel.

dialogue.speaker: IMMIGRATION OFFICER
dialogue.text: What are you coming here to do?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: I'm here for movies.

dialogue.speaker: IMMIGRATION OFFICER
dialogue.text: Movies...to be in the movies or to see movies?

dialogue.speaker: OLEG
dialogue.text: Yes.  No.  Both.  When I was a boy, I see movie at school called "It's a Wonderful Life" directed by Frank Capra. Ever since I want to come to America. Land of the free.  Home of the brave.  A land where anyone can be anything. As long as they are white.

dialogue.speaker: IMMIGRATION OFFICER
dialogue.text: Excuse me?

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: No.  Go ahead.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Thanks.  Appreciate it.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: So the way you see it, two crack heads burned themselves up?

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: That's what it looks like to me.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: And while they're burning up, they're still goin' down on each other?  You got to hand it to them.

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, some people got their priorities straight.

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: What was that?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Evidence.  Of a homicide.

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: I'll take him.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: No way!  He's mine!

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: We're takin' him.  Don't argue!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: He's my collar!

dialogue.speaker: LEON
dialogue.text: Well, he killed my partner!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: He's yours but I take him in!  I'll drive him to the precinct, you can have him but I'm walkin' him in.

dialogue.speaker: MUGGER
dialogue.text: Got any spare change?  How 'bout a spare twenty?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Look, I don't have time for you, get out of my way!!

dialogue.speaker: MUGGER
dialogue.text: Alright, how 'bout all your fuckin' money?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Okay, you're under arrest!  Now you happy?

dialogue.speaker: MUGGER
dialogue.text: Fire Department?  Firemen don't carry guns.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Oh yeah?  Guess again.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: I'll send a cop back for you.

dialogue.speaker: MUGGER
dialogue.text: Hey.  C'mon, you can't leave me like this.  Some freak'll come by and stab me!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: You okay?

dialogue.speaker: MUGGER
dialogue.text: A dog pissed on me!!  I'm gonna sue you for this!  You violated my civil rights!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Your civil rights?!  You tried to rob me!  I could arrest you right now! You're lucky you're walking away from this.  Now get outta here.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: What's that on your forehead, Max? That's a nice attention getter.

dialogue.speaker: MAX
dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm religious.  I'm not an Atheist like you!  Now, are you guys gonna arrest me, or not?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: How did you start the fire this time?

dialogue.speaker: MAX
dialogue.text: I used an accelerant.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Yeah?  What kind?

dialogue.speaker: MAX
dialogue.text: Hey, by the way, I'm really sorry about your wife leavin' you.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: Where you been, man?  We got a celebrity!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: I heard.  Who the hell let them up there?

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: I don't know, you think Eddie will give me his autograph?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: You see anything in the crowd?  Anybody suspicious?

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: Naw - I'm sure the suspect's not here.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, why?

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: 'Cause Eddie woulda locked him up by now!

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: Nah, not at all.  Detective Flemming - Bobby Korfin.  My Uncle Tony worked with you at 2-1 back when you were a rookie.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Could you put out the cigar?  Part of the job is picking up scents.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Mouth's clean, too.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: Clean?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Don't blow your nose!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: The smoke'll permeate your nostrils - burn 'em out.  Let it run.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: But you knew that, right?

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: You see Eddie's face when I gave him the timer?  Wish I had a picture of it.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: He knew all along.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: What??

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: That's why he was so quiet.  He was testing us.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: There was a woman - I think she wanted to talk to us.  She looked scared.  Oh shit!  Oh no!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Now that you know him, maybe you can get extra work in the next movie they make about him.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Maybe you can be his stand-in.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: -- From Czechoslovakia?  And how long have they been livin' in your building?  Alright, I'll be in touch when we know somethin'.  Milos and Tamina Karlova.  They were quiet and kept to themselves.  Landlord don't know who your girl is.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: How long they been livin' here?

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: You hear that question, Garcia?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: You go home.  I'm takin' your car and goin' back to the crime scene.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: Aren't you tired?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: If I go home I won't be able to fall asleep anyway.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Bobby, Bobby!  Where're you hit?!

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: It hurts.  Aw, Jesus!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Lay down.  Stay down, Bobby.

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: How was it?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Not good.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Get outta here!

dialogue.speaker: KORFIN
dialogue.text: What the hell happened?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: They were inside.  They booby trapped her apartment!

dialogue.speaker: TOMMY
dialogue.text: Room was registered to a Francis Capra.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Capra?  That's not Czech or Russian. Who said he sounded Russian?

dialogue.speaker: TOMMY
dialogue.text: The clerk?

dialogue.speaker: TOMMY
dialogue.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Don't you get it?  He knew he was gonna get caught!  That's why he videotaped Eddie's murder - he thinks he's gonna get off.

dialogue.speaker: TOMMY
dialogue.text: Don't stoop to his level!

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: Take the car.  Get outta here, Tommy.

dialogue.speaker: TOMMY
dialogue.text: Look, you can't shoot him in cold blood.

dialogue.speaker: JORDY
dialogue.text: GET OUTTA HERE NOW!!  GET IN THAT CAR AND DRIVE AWAY!!!  DO WHAT I SAY OR I'LL KILL YOU, TOO!!!

dialogue.speaker: STEPHEN GELLER
dialogue.text: This had nothing to do with shoes that didn't fit or my relationship with my father who, as you know, made a fortune selling penny loafers in the fifties. These people died because of the criminal actions of my doctor.

dialogue.speaker: ROBERT HAWKINS
dialogue.text: Your doctor?

dialogue.speaker: STEPHEN GELLER
dialogue.text: Yes.  My psychiatrist didn't insist that I stay on my medication.

dialogue.speaker: ROBERT HAWKINS
dialogue.text: ...so you feel absolutely no responsibility for killing these people?

dialogue.speaker: STEPHEN GELLER
dialogue.text: It was my finger that pulled the trigger, but I'm not morally responsible.  My psychiatrist knew what I was capable of.  How could I know. I'm not a doctor.

dialogue.speaker: ROBERT HAWKINS
dialogue.text: You seem very savvy for a man who's been found mentally incompetent to stand trial.

dialogue.speaker: STEPHEN GELLER
dialogue.text: Look, I'm a victim here, too.  I was a year away from getting my masters in Art, now I'll never graduate.  My life has been permanently disrupted.

dialogue.speaker: ROBERT HAWKINS
dialogue.text: Permanently disrupted?  Aren't you selling paintings now for quite a lot of money?  Hasn't this 'incident' as you call it, jump started your career as an artist?

dialogue.speaker: STEPHEN GELLER
dialogue.text: Look, I'm in here.  You call this a career move?

dialogue.speaker: ROBERT HAWKINS
dialogue.text: And isn't there a movie in the works about you?

dialogue.speaker: STEPHEN GELLER
dialogue.text: We're in negotiations, that's correct.

dialogue.speaker: ROBERT HAWKINS
dialogue.text: But doesn't the Son of Sam Law prevent criminals from profiting from their crimes?

dialogue.speaker: STEPHEN GELLER
dialogue.text: That doesn't apply to me because I'm not a criminal.  I'm not a criminal!  I wasn't convicted.

dialogue.speaker: B20
dialogue.text: SPACE STATTION 5 - LOUNGE

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Well, how nice to see you again, Elena. You're looking wonderful.

dialogue.speaker: B20
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I'm afraid I've only got a few minutes, but I'd love to.

dialogue.speaker: B20
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: She's wonderful.

dialogue.speaker: B20
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Well, I suppose they've been having a bit of trouble with some of the equipment.

dialogue.speaker: B20
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: How did they manage to do that without any communication?

dialogue.speaker: B20
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Dr. Smyslov, but I'm really not at liberty to discuss this.

dialogue.speaker: B20
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: We're trying to get there. I hope we can.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Hi. Frank... coming in, please.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Right. Just a sec.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Okay, come on down.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Dave, if you've a minute, I'd like your advice on something.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Sure, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Well, it's nothing really important, but it's annoying.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: What's up?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: It's about my salary cheques.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Well I got the papers on my official up-grading to AGS-19 two weeks before we left.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: That's right. Well, naturally, I didn't say anything to Payroll. I assumed they'd start paying me at the higher grade on the next pay cheque. But it's been almost three weeks now and I'm still being paid as an AGS-18.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Interesting that you mention it, because I've got the same problem.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Really.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Yesterday, I finally called the Accounting Office at Mission Control, and all they could tell me was that they'd received the AGS-19 notification for the other three but not mine, and apparently not yours either.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Not really. They just said it might be because we trained at Houston and they trained in Marshall, and that we're being charged against differ- ent accounting offices.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: It's possible.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Well, what do you think we ought to do about it?

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I don't think we should make any fuss about it yet. I'm sure they'll straighten it out.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I must say, I never did understand why they split us into two groups for training.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: No. I never did, either.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I suppose the idea was specialized training.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I suppose so. Though, of course, there's a more sinister explanation.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Oh?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Yes. You must have heard the rumour that went around during orbital check-out.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: No, as a matter of fact, I didn't.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Oh, well, apparently there's something about the mission that the sleeping beauties know that we don't know, and that's why we were trained separately and that's why they were put to sleep before they were even taken aboard.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I don't know. All I heard is that there's something about the mission we weren't told.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: That seems very unlikely.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Yes, I thought so.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Of course, it would be very easy for us to find out now.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: How?

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Just ask Hal. It's conceivable they might keep something from us, but they'd never keep anything from Hal.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: That's true.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Not really. Though, it is strange when you think about it. It didn't really make any sense to keep us apart during training.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Yes, but it's to fantastic to think that they'd keep something from us.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I know. It would be almost inconceivable.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: But not completely inconceivable?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I suppose it isn't logically impossible.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I guess it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Still, all we have to do is ask Hal.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Well, that's something.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Yes, I don't know what to make of it.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I suppose computers have been known to be wrong.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Yes, but it's more likely that the tolerances on our testing gear are too low.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Anyway, it's just as well that we replace it. Better safe than sorry.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Good morning. How's it going?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Are you reasonably awake?

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Oh, I'm fine, I'm wide awake. What's up?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Well... Hal's reported the AO-unit about to fail again.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: You're kidding.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I don't know. Hal said he thought it might be the assembly procedure.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Two units in four days. How many spares do we have?

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Two more.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Well, I hope there's nothing wrong with the assembly on those. Other- wise we're out of business.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Hal?

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: It's the last one.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Well, now that we've got one that's actually failed, we should be able to figure out what's happened and fix it.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I didn't do that Frank. I took particular care not to freeze them.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I guess you don't know your own strength, old boy.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I guess not.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: I think I'll have to go out and burn them off.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Roger.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Frank, but I don't think I can answer that question without knowing everything that all of you know.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: He's got a point.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Sorry to interrupt the festivities, Dave, but I think we've got a problem.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: What is it, Hal?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: MY F.P.C. shows an impending failure of the antenna orientation unit.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: The unit is still operational, Dave. but it will fail within seventy-two hours.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I understand Hal. We'll take care of it. Please, let me have the hard copy.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Not now, Hal, I'd like to talk to you about something.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Sure, Dave, what's up?

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: You know that we checked the two AO-units that you reported in imminent failure condition?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Yes, I know.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: You probably also know that we found them okay.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Yes, I know that. But I can assure you that they were about to fail.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I'm not questioning your word, Dave, but it's just not possible. I'm not capable of being wrong.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Hal, is there anything bothering you?  Anything that might account for this problem?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Look, Dave, I know that you're sincere and that you're trying to do a competent job, and that you're trying to be helpful, but I can assure the problem is with the AO-units, and with your test gear.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Okay, Hal, well let's see the way things go from here on.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Naturally, Dave, I'm not pleased that the AO-unit has failed, but I hope at least this has restored your confidence in my integrity and reliability. I certainly wouldn't want to be disconnected, even temporarily, as I have never been disconnected in my entire service history.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I'm sorry about the misunderstanding, Hal.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Well, don't worry about it.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: And don't you worry about it.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Is your confidence in me fully restored?

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Yes, it is, Hal.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Well, that's a relief. You know I have the greatest enthusiasm possible for the mission.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Too bad about Frank, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I suppose you're pretty broken up about it?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I suppose it's because you've been under a lot of stress, but have you forgotten that they're not supposed to be revived for another three months.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: The antenna has to be replaced.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Repairing the antenna is a pretty dangerous operation.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: It doesn't have to be, Hal. It's more dangerous to be out of touch with Earth. Let me have manual control, please.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I don't really agree with you, Dave. My on-board memory store is more than capable of handling all the mission requirements.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: If you're determined to revive the crew now, I can handle the whole thing myself. There's no need for you to trouble.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I'm goin to do this myself, Hal. Let me have the control, please.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Look, Dave your've probably got a lot to do. I suggest you leave it to me.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Hal, switch to manual hibernation control.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I don't like to assert myself, Dave, but it would be much better now for you to rest. You've been involved in a very stressful situation.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I can tell from the tone of your voice, Dave, that you're upset. Why don't you take a stress pill and get some rest.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Hal, I'm in command of this ship. I order you to release the manual hibernation control.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Dave, but in accordance with sub-routine C1532/4, quote, When the crew are dead or incapacitated, the computer must assume control, unquote. I must, therefore, override your authority now since you are not in any condition to intel- ligently exercise it.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Hal, unless you follow my instructions, I shall be forced to disconnect you.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: I am prepared to do that anyway.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I know that you've had that on your mind for some time now, Dave, but it would be a crying shame, since I am so much more capable of carrying out this mission than you are, and I have such enthusiasm and confi- dence in the mission.

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Listen to me very carefully, Hal. Unless you immediately release the hibernation control and follow every order I give from this point on, I will immediately got to control central and carry out a complete disconnection.

dialogue.speaker: C12
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Yes, I remember you mentioning it. I got mine about the same time.

dialogue.speaker: C12
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Did they have any explanation for this?

dialogue.speaker: C12
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Well, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: C12
dialogue.text: CONINUED

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Well... it's silly, but... if you want to, why don't you?

dialogue.speaker: C12
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Still, you really don't believe it, do you?

dialogue.speaker: C12
dialogue.text: CONTINUED

dialogue.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogue.text: Well, the only important aspect of the mission are: where are we going, what will we do when we get there, when are we coming back, and... why are we going?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I'm at Space Station Five, darling. How are you?

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: I'm fine, Daddy. When are you coming home?

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: I'm having a party tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Yes, I know that sweetheart.

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: Are you coming to my party?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: No, I'm sorry, darling, I told you I won't be home for a few days.

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: When are you coming home?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: In three days, darling, I hope.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: One, two, three. Can I speak to Mommy?

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: Mommy's out to the hair- dresser.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Where is Mrs. Brown?

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: She's in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Okay, sweetheart. Well, I have to go now. Tell Mommy that I called.

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: How many days until you come home?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Three, darling. One... two ... three. Be sure to tell Mommy I called.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Okay, sweetheart. Have a lovely Birthday Party tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: Thank you, Daddy.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I'll wish you a happy Birthday now and I'll see you soon. All right, Darling?

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: Yes, Daddy.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: 'Bye, 'bye, now, sweetheart.

dialogue.speaker: CHILD
dialogue.text: Goodbye, Daddy.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: CO-PILOT
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Well, how's it going back there?

dialogue.speaker: CO-PILOT
dialogue.text: Well, I've heard more and more people talk of an epidemic.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: I suppose it was bound to happen sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: CO-PILOT
dialogue.text: Berkeley told me that they think it came from contamination on a returning Mars flight.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Yes, well, whatever it is, they're certainly not fooling around. This is the first flight they allowed in for more than a week.

dialogue.speaker: CO-PILOT
dialogue.text: I was working out what this trip must cost, taking him up there by himself and coming back empty.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: I'll bet it's a fortune.

dialogue.speaker: ELENA
dialogue.text: And your charming little daughter?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Oh, she's growing up very fast. As a matter of fact, she's six tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: ELENA
dialogue.text: Oh, that's such a delightful age.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: How is gregor?

dialogue.speaker: ELENA
dialogue.text: He's fine. But I'm afraid we don't get a chance to see each other very much these days.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Well, where are all of you off to?

dialogue.speaker: ELENA
dialogue.text: Clavius Control came on the air just long enough to transmit their refusal.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Well, that does sound very odd.

dialogue.speaker: ELENA
dialogue.text: Are you sure you won't change your mind about a drink?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: No, thank you... and I'm afraid now I really must be going.

dialogue.speaker: ELENA
dialogue.text: Well, I hope that you and your wife can come to the I.A.C. conference in June.

dialogue.speaker: ELENA
dialogue.text: Well, Gregor and I will look forward to seeing you.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Thank you. It's been a great pleasure to meet all of you... Dr. Smyslov.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: How do you do, Mr. Miller?

dialogue.speaker: MILLER
dialogue.text: I'm terribly sorry. I was just on my way down to meet you. I saw your ship dock and I knew I had plenty of time, and I was on my way out of the office when, suddenly, the phone rang.

dialogue.speaker: MILLER
dialogue.text: Well, thank you very much for being so understanding.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Please, it really doesn't matter.

dialogue.speaker: MILLER
dialogue.text: Well.. Did you have a pleaant flight?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Yes, very pleasant.

dialogue.speaker: MILLER
dialogue.text: Well, shall we go through Documentation?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Yes, I think so. Just about then.

dialogue.speaker: MILLER
dialogue.text: I suppose you saw the work on our new section while you were docking.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Yes, it's coming along very well.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Oh, I really don't have time for a drink. If it's all right I'll just sit for a minute and then I've got to be off.

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Are you quite sure?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Yes, really, thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Well, as it happens, I'm on my way up to the moon

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Are you, by any chance, going up to your base at Clavius?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Yes,as a matter of fact, I am.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, but I'm not sure I know what you mean.

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Well, it's just for the past two weeks there have been some extremely odd things happening at Clavius.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Yes. Well, for one thing, whenever you phone the base, all you can get is a recording which repeats that the phone lines are temporarily out of order.

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Yes, well at first we thought that was the explanation, but it's been going on for the past ten days.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: You mean you haven't been able to get anyone at the base for ten days?

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: That's right.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I see.

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Yes, and I'm afaid there's going to be a bit of a row about it. Denying the men permission to land was a direct violation of the I.A.S. convention.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Yes... Well, I hope the crew got back safely.

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Fortunately, they did.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Well, I'm glad about that.

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Dr. Floyd, at the risk of pressing you on a point you seem reticent to discuss, may I ask you a straightforward question?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Certainly.

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: Quite frankly, we have had some very reliable intelligence reports that a quite serious epidemic has broken out at Clavius. Something, apperently, of an unknown origin. Is this, in fact, what has happened?

dialogue.speaker: SMYSLOV
dialogue.text: This epidemic could easily spread to our base, Dr. Floyd. We should be given all the facts.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Dr. Smyslov... I'm not permitted to discuss this.

dialogue.speaker: MICHAELS
dialogue.text: Dr. Floyd, how long do you think this can be kept under wraps?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I'm afraid it can and it will be kept under wraps as long as it is deemed to be necessary by the Council. And of course you know that the Council has requested that formal security oaths are to be obtained in writing from every- one who had any knowledge of this event. There must be adequate time for a full study to be made of the situation before any con- sideration can be given to making a public announcement.

dialogue.speaker: MICHAELS
dialogue.text: Yes, it does. The sub-surface structure shows that it was deliberately buried about four million years ago.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: How can you tell it was deliberately buried?

dialogue.speaker: MICHAELS
dialogue.text: By the deformation between the mother rock and the fill.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Any clue as to what it is?

dialogue.speaker: MICHAELS
dialogue.text: Not really. It's completely inert. No sound or energy sources have been detected. The surface is made of something incredibly hard and we've been barely able to scratch it. A laser drill

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: But you don't have any idea as to what it is?

dialogue.speaker: MICHAELS
dialogue.text: Tomb, shine, survey-marker spare part, take your choice.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Any ideas about the colour?

dialogue.speaker: MICHAELS
dialogue.text: Well, not really. At first glance, black would suggest something sun-powered, but then why would anyone deliberately bury a sun- powered device?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Has it been exposed to any sun before now?

dialogue.speaker: MICHAELS
dialogue.text: I don't think it has, but I'd like to check that. Simpson, what's the log on that?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Oh, marvellous. It's the first real sleep I've had for the past two days.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: There's nothing like weightless sleep for a complete rest.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: When do we arrive at Clavius?

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: We're scheduled to dock in about seven hours. Is there anything we can do for you?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Oh, no, thank you. The two girls have taken wonderful care of me. I'm just fine.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Incidentally, Dr. Floyd, I wonder if I can have a word with you about the security arrangements?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Well... the crew is confined to the ship when we land at Clavius. We have to stay inside for the time it take to refit - about twenty-four hours. And then we're going to back empty.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I see.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: I take it this is something to do with the trouble they're having up at Clavius?

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Well, I'll tell you why I ask. You see, I've got a girl who works in the Auditing Department of the Territorial Administrator and I haven't been able to get her on the phone for the past week or so, and with all these stories one hears, I'm a little concerned about her.

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: I see. Well, I'm sorry about that. I wouldn't think there's any cause for alarm.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Yes, well, I wouldn't have been too concerned about it, except I've heard these stories about the epidemic and, as a matter of fact, I've heard that ten people have died already.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Well, fine. Thanks very much, anyway, and I hope you don't mind me asking?

dialogue.speaker: FLOYD
dialogue.text: No, of course, Captain, I can understand your concern.

dialogue.speaker: PILOT
dialogue.text: Well, thank you very much, and please let us know if there is anything we can do to make your trip more comfortable.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Right. Hal, tell me whether the following statements are true or false.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I will if I can, Frank.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Our Mission Profile calls for Discovery going to Saturn. True or false?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: True.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Our transit time is 257 days. Is that true?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: That's true.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: That's true.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Approximately five years after we go into hibernation, the recovery vehicle will make rendezous with us and bring us back. Is this true?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: That's true

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: There is no other purpose for this mission than to carry out a continuation of the space program, and to further our general knowledge of the planets. Is that true?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: That's true.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Thank you very much, Hal.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Hal, have pod arms secure the component.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Roger.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Five by five, Frank.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Hal, I'm going out now to replace the A.O. unit.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I understand.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Hal, maintain normal E.V.A. condition.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Roger.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Hal, check all airlock doors secure.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Pod Bay is decompressed. All doors are secure. You are free to open pod bay doors.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Opening pod bay doors.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Yes, Hal, what's up?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: It looks like we have another bad A.O. unit. My FPC shows another impending failure.

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: I know you did, Frank, but I assure you there was an impending failure.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Let me see the tracking alignment display.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: Do you have any idea of what is causing this fault?

dialogue.speaker: HAL
dialogue.text: Not really, Frank. I think there may be a flaw in the assembly procedure.

dialogue.speaker: POOLE
dialogue.text: All right, Hal. We'll take care of it. Let me have the hard copy, please.

dialogue.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: LUTHER
dialogue.text: I want to pick up my car.

dialogue.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogue.text: Name?

dialogue.speaker: LUTHER
dialogue.text: Hammond.

dialogue.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogue.text: This is three years old.

dialogue.speaker: LUTHER
dialogue.text: Yeah, I've been busy.

dialogue.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogue.text: We don't wash 'em, ya know.

dialogue.speaker: LUTHER
dialogue.text: How about chargin' the battery?

dialogue.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogue.text: That we do. And we put air in the tires. I'll even sell you some gas if you need it.

dialogue.speaker: LUTHER
dialogue.text: Great, just great.

dialogue.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Vodka.

dialogue.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogue.text: Maybe you better have a Black Russian.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: No, man, I think I'll have a vodka.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Now how's your memory doin'?

dialogue.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogue.text: Fuck off.  I don't know what the hell you're talkin' about.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Maybe I better ask around, see what your pals think.

dialogue.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogue.text: I don't give a shit who you ask.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I don't give a damn about his girl...

dialogue.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogue.text: Look, give me a break, you're going to have to settle for her place.  It's the only thing I know.

dialogue.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogue.text: I'm tellin' ya, I'm giving you all I know.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Try obeyin' the law once in awhile, and I won't have to hassle you...

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: Maybe you shoulda stole a better truck, Tonto.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: You got a real big mouth, convict.

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: I want to drive awhile.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: I ain't tired yet.

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: Maybe after we get done with him I'm gonna buy us some girls.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: Whaddya mean, buy?

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: Pros.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: Pay money?

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: Yeah, dummy.  Money.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: I never paid for it in my life.

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: It's better when you pay... they let you do anything.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: They always let me do anything. I don't want to pay for it.  I never paid for it in my life.

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: Just do what I say, okay? We'll pay for the girls and have a good time... Don't you trust me?

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: Maybe that's where I'm gonna cut your throat.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: He's just kiddin', you just keep doin' what I tell ya, you'll be okay.

dialogue.speaker: BILLY
dialogue.text: Hey, what about me?

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: And I need one more for my pal. Yeah. Make her an Indian. No, not a turban, you know, a squaw.

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: I'm candy...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Excuse me, baby, but if i don't get some action tonight, I'm gonna bust.  You interested?

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: Hey, what kind of talk is that?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Oh ... You're a schoolteacher...

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: No, I go to a school to learn how to do hair. It's a government program. But really I want to be a model - and I am definitely not sellin'.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Goodbye.

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: Hey, don't you think a hair stylists got any interest in gettin' it on?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Here you go sweetheart, throw it my way.

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: You're in a hurry.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Yeah, i been waiting three years.

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: You just quit bein' a priest or somethin'?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: No, baby, nothin' like that. Look, there's a place across the street. We can go right over there...

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: What's the matter with my place?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: No, it's gotta be here and now. Believe me. Only I don't have the damn money for a room...

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: Well, maybe I'll see you later ...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Here's hoping, baby...

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: Hello, again.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I just struck it rich... I think we can do a little business.  As a matter of fact, I think we can have a party.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Here you go, baby.

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: Hey, don't do that.  I said I wasn't a pro, remember?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Hey, no, I'm tryin' to be nice. Buy yourself something pretty. I'd do it, but I got to go.  I got this cop waitin' for me...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I'll buy ya the best dinner in San Francisco...how'd that be? Then we'll go dancin', okay?

dialogue.speaker: CANDY
dialogue.text: Now you're talkin'. See ya...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I said police.  Now drop the goddamn gun.

dialogue.speaker: CASEY
dialogue.text: Don't give me that police shit. You drop it.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: How about it?

dialogue.speaker: CASEY
dialogue.text: I used to go with him...I don't know where the hell he is.  I haven't seen him for two weeks. And I don't think I will.  He owes me money...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I hear you've got visitors.

dialogue.speaker: CASEY
dialogue.text: Would you guys...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: No time for any of that crap any more, lady... I'll rip your lungs out if you don't answer fast.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You and the other one, you're still Billy's girls. You always were his girls...

dialogue.speaker: CASEY
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Sure, i'm crazy in love with him, who wouldn't be...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You're gonna help us take him.

dialogue.speaker: CASEY
dialogue.text: No chance.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: He can live or die ... You let us in and he's got a chance to make it.  Otherwise, he gets ventilated.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Where's ganz?

dialogue.speaker: CASEY
dialogue.text: In the back.  Down the other corridor.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You lying son of a bitch...

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: What are you talking about? We didn't kill her ...

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: After I get outta this, cop...I'm gonna live forever...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I don't think you're gonna make it.

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: Whaddya mean...I got your gun ... I got his money... I got everything...

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: I got hit.  I can't believe it. I got shot.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You're done.  End of story.

dialogue.speaker: GANZ
dialogue.text: I ain't gonna beg for my life. It ain't cool.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You got a name, cop?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Try Cates.  And let's talk in private, okay?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Sure, anything you want.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You here to write my life story?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Not likely, Reggie.  Maybe I just need some help.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, I noticed...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Ganz is in jail.  He's gonna be there two years after I'm on the street.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Didn't work out that way.  He busted out with a big Indian. They capped two guards on a road gang. Nice meeting you Reggie.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I can deliver Ganz.  But you gotta get me outta here first.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You're crazy.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I can help you, man, but you gotta get me out.  I got to be on the street.  Get me outta here.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: What's the big deal about you bein' on the street?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I got a lot to protect.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Bullshit.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: It's the only way you're gonna get Ganz.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I'll think about it.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: This prison gives out $400 suits?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: What are you talkin' about?  This suit's mine.  It cost $900.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: We're supposed to be after a killer, not a string of hookers...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Listen, it may be a little out of date. You know, I got a reputation for lookingreal sharp with the ladies...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I don't need to hear your jive. I already got that department taken care of...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You got a girl... shit... the generosityof women never ceases to amaze me.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Hey, no way.  Take off the bracelets or no deal.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You just don't get it, do your Reggie?  There isn't any deal. I own your ass.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: No way to start a partnership.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Get this.  We ain't partners. We ain't brothers.  We ain't friends. I'm puttin' you down and keepin' you down until Ganz is locked up or dead.  And if Ganz gets away, you're gonna be sorry we ever met.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Shit.  I'm already sorry.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: It looks like you bought it off one of the brothers.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Okay, let's get down to it.  I did my part and got you out.  So now you tell me where we're goin'?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Don't worry, I got a move for ya. An awesome move. A guy named Luther. Ganz'll be paying him a visit.  We go to him right away.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Luther was part of the gang?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: What gang you talkin' about, Jack?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I can read a police file, shithead, and quit calling me Jack.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Just an expression man, don't mean nothin'.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I don't give a damn.  It happens to be my name.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Then what're you complainin' about? At least nobody's calling you shithead....

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I may call you worse than that.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Just up the street, the other side, over there ... Now, don't bother knockin' on the door. Luther ain't the kind of guy that looks for company.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Your pal nuts enough to take a shot at me?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Luther ain't the reliable type. I don't want you shot yet, Cates ... not before you been a help to me.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I'm helpin' you, huh?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Quit playin' cop and undo this cuff, Jack, I need to talk to this man.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I'm tellin' you to drop the Goddam gun.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I got a whole thing about people pointin' guns at me.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Just throw me the Goddamn gun.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Hey, this works pretty good.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Want to try it again?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: What do you think?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I think you better put him on ice, man.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: He's gotta take that call ... if there is one.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: If you let him run around till Tuesday, he's gonna run right to Ganz and warn him. Ain't you, motherfucker?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: We're on the move. Let's go. As they walk toward a corridor.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Do you know how close I was to getting some trim.  And you fucked' it up.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, my ass bleeds for you. And I didn't get you out so you could go on a Goddamn "trim" hunt... stop moaning.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Speakin' of moans my Stomach is startin' to growl.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: We eat when I say we eat.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Bullshit ... I ain't moving  till I get something to eat. You've been treating me like shit ever since I came out here.  If you don't like it, you can take me back to the penitentiary and kiss my hungry black ass good-bye.  And I want some food some place nice.. Some good people, nice music...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm hungry too. I know of a place. Let's go eat.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Yeah, I want mandolins, flowers... They move off down the corridor.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Who'd you call on the phone back at the booking station?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Just get in the car and keep your mouth shut.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You really do have onoe, huh, Jack... what's her problem besides you?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: She's got the same complaint as half the Goddamn population.  She can't get the job she's trained for and it pisses her off... Anyway, what the fuck do you care?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Now, where we goin', convict?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Mission District.  Gonna find us an Indian.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I don't give out the details.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Last night, two nights ago, three?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Last night.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You have a good time?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Sure.  Then we had a fight this morning.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: At least you took care of business and got the important part in before she came down on you...Tell me a little about her.  She got great tits?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Well?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: It's a long shot, but...Billy used to tend bar here a few years back. I heard him talk about it.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: This part of town, they'll make us for heat the second we walk in. Just back me up like you've got a piece...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Back you up?  Now why would I wanna do that?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: If they kick my ass, they'll sure as hell carve yours up...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: But you can handle it all right, huh? Real amazin' how far a gun and a badge can carry some cats...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Bullshit.  Attitude and experience get you through...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I been in a lot of bars where a white cop rousted me and some of the brothers. All those clowns ever had going for 'em was a gun and a badge...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You need five years training to handle a joint like...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Hey, you wanna bet?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I got two problems.  Number one, I'm not playin' games.  Number two, you got nothin' to bet with.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: If we come outta this joint with Ganz' phone number, or a dead Indian, or anything else useful, then you could turn the other way for half an hour while I get laid...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Why?  Anybody that talks about women as much as you do probably can't get it up anyway.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: That's never been one of my problems.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I'll tell you what happens if you lose... you tell the truth for once.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: What are you talkin' about?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You tell me what Ganz busted out for, he's after a lot more than just gettin' out of jail.  And whatever it is, you're part of it.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I don't know what you're talking about. I just wanna see Ganz nailed.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: The bet's off.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I'm gonna enjoy this ... here, I'll even loan you my badge.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I thought you said bullshit and experience are all it takes.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: This place don't seem real popular with the brothers.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: My kind of place. I always liked country boys.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: That wasn't necessary, buddy. I got this under control.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Some of us citizens are with you all the way, Officer.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You made that move, huh?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: While you're at it, You can give me the switchblade, too.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: There.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Must be billy's girl.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Come on.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Let's go.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Wait a minute.  Maybe these ladies would like to go a few laps with us.  How about it? I been nearly three years in prison and...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: This sucks.  A maniac gets hold of my gun and goes all over the streets killing people with it. So, instead of me being where I oughta be, which is in bed giving my girl the high, hard one, I'm out here doing this shit, roaming around with some overdressed, charcoal-colored loser like you.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You wanna leave, man?  Let me take care of Ganz all by myself.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You?  Don't make me laugh.  You can't take care of shit.  You've been dicking me around since we started on this turd-hunt.  All you're good for is games... So far, what I got outta you is nothin'...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I'm impressed with you too, Jack you did a real good job of busting up a couple of dykes bedded down for the night.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Luther knew more than he told me and so do you...Now you better tell we what the fuck this is all about.  I gave you 48 hours to come up with something and the clock's runnin' ...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Maybe I don't like the way you ask.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Who gives a Goddamn what you think? You're just a crook that's got a weekendpass ... You're not even a name anymore. Just a spear- chucker with a Goddamn number stenciled on the back of his prison fatigues...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, right.  You want to try again?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Naw, you'd just call your pals back to bail you out one more time.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: They saved your ass, convict.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: One thing's for sure, Jack. That's how you'll tell the story.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I been waiting a long time for some money.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: How much?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Half a million.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Just tell me about the money.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Me and my bunch hit a dealer in the middle of a sale. It's the kind of money nobody ever reports stolen. I was sittin' pretty, livin' in the high cotton, then somebody fingered me for another job. ... Some psycho who's out there capping people with some cop's gun.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: He's after your money.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You catch on real fast...Okay, Jack, let's talk deal. How much of my money you gonna let me keep?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: We split 50-50?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Not likely, convict.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You gonna let me keep any of it?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Depends on how things work out. I believe in the merit system. So far you haven't built up any points.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Where's the money?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: In the trunk of a car.  A lot better than under a mattress, right?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Right, partner.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Get this. We ain't partners. We ain't brothers. We ain't friends. If Ganz gets away with my money, you're gonna be sorry we ever met.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Right.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Where's the goddamn car?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You're a real case, you know that, Jack?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: This'll show you how smart I am. I got it parked.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: ...For three years?  Let's hope it wasn't a tow-away zone.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You just drove by it.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You son of a bitch. You knew where the money was all along and all we had to do was come here and wait. I almost got my ass blown off twice tonight for nothing.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I wasn't sure the money was still there until we saw Luther. You almost got your ass shot off for nothing once, not twice, Jack.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Shit.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You took a big chance, leaving this here all this time.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Not really.  I figured Ganz was put down for a long time.  And I knew Luther would never job me on his own.  He's too chickenshit.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Guess what?  Luther just got in line.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Musta got some primo bondsman.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Jesus Christ.  That's a disgrace The guy pulls a gun on a cop and he's out in 24 hours.  I tell you some of the courts these days are just a fucking revolving door.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Jesus Christ, look at all the dust on my car...why in the hell don't he take it to a car wash?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Didn't know you darker people went in for foreign jobs.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I had no choice. Some white asshole bought the last piece of shit skyblue Cadillac.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You'd think the guy'd be smart enough to know he was being tailed.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Tryin' to save his girl, man. He's in another world.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: If I was his size and had Ganz on my ass, I'd  just leave town.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I'm tellin' you the man's in love... he wants to be a hero for his girl.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah, does bein' in love make you stupid?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I suppose you'd never be like Luther and let a woman get to you...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I let women get to me.  The quest for pussy is the meaning of life ... I got my own personal philosophy about 'em.  Keep women separate from guns, money and business ... women are for spending money.  They got nothing to do with helping you make it.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: That ain't philosophy.  That's common sense.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Say, do you always work people over like you did Luther?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: If they don't tell me what I need to know...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Doesn't it get... Tiring?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I'm not in this 'cause it's fun. I'm not into hitting guys 'cause it makes me feel good either... I do it 'cause it works-...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You got a very depressing view of life, man... you gotta smile once in awhile...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Maybe Luther hopes Ganz'll give him a piece of your money...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: If he's hoping that then he's dumber than I think he is, which would be amazin', cause I already think he's real dumb.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: A long time agb Luther must of got the shit beat out of him so bad it just rattled his brain ... that would account for him making so many wrong moves in a row...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, it doesn't look like he's gonna make it as a dangerous tough guy...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You know, I'd be embarrassed if I let my wheels go the way you've done with this job.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: What you don't understand is, I don't give a damn about how this thing looks.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: No class...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Class isn't somethin' you buy, punk. Look at you, five hundred dollar suit and you're still a lowlife.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: We're getting too close ... Cates, what's the matter, you been takin' dumb pills?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, most cops are pretty dumb... But since you're the one that landed in jail what's that make you?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: That was in style a couple years back, man.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Right. if you ever switch from armed robbery to pimping, then you're all set.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Bullshit. Then i'm staying with the money.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You stay with me...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: No way...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Hey, Jack, how ya doin'? What took you so long to call, man? I been waitin' ... I'm at Vroman's up in the Fillmore. Yeah, Vroman's... 'Course you don't hang out here; it's for the brothers.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I'll be there in a minute. You don't move your ass, right?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Where's luther?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Be polite. Say hello.  This is Candy.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Hello. And goodbye.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: What about Luther?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: What about Ganz?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: We missed.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You missed ... Luther took a taxi to the hotel across the street. Made a phone call.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Maybe we should pay Luther a visit.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Let him get some sleep.  He's going to need it.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: They must have set up a meeting for the morning; Luther left an 8 am wake-up and put up the "Don't Disturb" sign.  He's trading his girl for the money.  All we have to do to grab Ganz is not go blind.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: So you took the rest of the night off...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Tell me something.  Why didn't you just take the money off Luther and split?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Forget it. I want Ganz as bad as you do and I got some other news for you...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I don't know why, but I'm going to let you keep it. Maybe because you told me you had it, or maybe just because I'm too tired to argue...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You sure that's the reason?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Thanks for callin' in... and I guess Maybe... Look, I'm sorry I called you Watermellon nigger... those kinds of things. I was just leanin' on ya, doin' my job.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Bein' good at your job don't explain everything, Jack ...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah. Guess not.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, I see her.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: I can just take her right across the street to Luther's hotel.  All I need is some money for the room.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: That was quick.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: When you been in prison three years, it don't take long. Let's go.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Luther's on the move...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Notice something funny about that bus?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah. It missed the last four stops.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Hey, how'd my car get here?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I had it impounded.  Come on, we'll use it for haulin' you back to the slam.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Back to jail in my own car.  Ganz got away. Got all my money. It just don't seem right.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I don't know about you, but I could use a drink... I'll buy you one.  It'll be my good-bye present.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Sorry we didn't do better, Jack. I feel like I let you down.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Naw, you didn't let me down.  It was a long shot all the way.  We gave 'em a good run at it.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Yeah, but we didn't get 'em.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: It's late, they're closing...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Yeah, well the only woman of the Indian's we ran into was shacked up with her dyke girlfriend.  I guess she went with him before she came outta the Closet ... They both looked mad enough to kill him...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Yeah, too bad.  They were real nice lookin' too...In bed together, hardly any clothes one watching TV...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Do I get to kiss her too?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: If she's right, and if you don't screw up.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: What if your girl's theory turns out to be bullshit?  I mean, they could be in Rio de Janeiro.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I've got to play it rough with them. If they know anything, I'm gonna know it.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Hey, there she is...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Whatever play I maker just back me up.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: If we run into Billy first, let me try and talk him in.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Sure, I'll give you a shot at it, but Ganz is mine.  You know, that big Indian plays it for keeps...

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Yeah, and I know Ganz sure ain't no sweetheart... I wouldn't like it if this partnership ended before it gets started.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Partnership?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Well, you got to admit we come a long way.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You okay?

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Yeah.  But I wasn't there for a second.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: You did pick a real strange time to go and be brave all on your own...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Okay, reggie, start bustin' my chops... Tell me how great you were with that chick.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Hey, Jack, real men don't have to go in for that macho bullshit ... but I was fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, Cates.  I've been waitin' three years for that.  I don't think it's fair, man. What about the merit system.? You were gonnna give me a few thousand.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: There's nothin' to talk about.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: It's your money.  It'll be here in six months when you get out.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: And you're tellin' me you don't want any of this cash?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: That's right. Not my style, Reggie..

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: You are an awesomely weird cop. Sure wish there were more like you runnin' around out here.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: No, you don't. If I ever get word of you steppin' over the line again, I'm gonna ventilate that suit of yours.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: Spare met Jack. I'm into legit investments from here on in.

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogue.text: No trouble, Jack. But, listen, suppose I stay a crook?  Where'd you get the idea that you could catch me?

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: I want to be left alone on this one. Algren was killed with my gun.

dialogue.speaker: HADEN
dialogue.text: Yeah, I read the report...

dialogue.speaker: CATES
dialogue.text: Hey, the bastard's got my gun.  I want it back.

dialogue.speaker: HADEN
