dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Do you carry a gun, Mr. Welles?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I wear a gun when I can tell a client expects me to.  Other than that, there's never any reason.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Just curious.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: My husband was the only one with the combination to this safe.  I knew about it, but as far as I was concerned it was none of my business.  Not till now, that is.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You hired someone to open it.  I'll bet the lawyer loved that.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: There was nothing he could do.  My husband left everything to me.  I prevented anyone from seeing the contents.  I felt these were my husband's private things.  I didn't... I didn't realize...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Do you want to tell me what you found?

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Cash, stock certificates, and this...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: It's a film... of a girl being murdered.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I'm afraid I don't...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: This is a movie showing a girl being murdered.  She's sitting on a bed, and a man rapes her... and he begins to cut her with a knife...  I only watched what I could.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: I didn't know what to think.  I can't tell you how horrible it's been, to know this belonged to my husband.  To know that he watched this... this atrocity.  But, I can't go to the police...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Mrs. Christian... please, will you sit down a moment?  I want you to listen carefully. What you're talking about is a "snuff film."  But, from what I know, snuff films are a kind of... urban myth.  Like, red light district folklore.  There's no such thing, I can assure you.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Please, believe me.  This is probably a stag film.  Simulated rape.  Hard to stomach, and it might seem real, but there are ways of making it look realistic... fake blood and special effects...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: If you were to study it you'd see the camera cutting away... you'd see the tricks they can play...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: I'm telling you it's not that.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I'm sure it is.  It's probably something your husband was given as a bad joke.  More than likely he never even watched it.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Will you watch it and see for yourself?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Of course.  But, I'm certain it's nothing to worry about.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You... you need to go to the police.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: I told you I can't, not yet.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You don't have any other choice.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: No.  For me to live with the ruin of my husband's name, I need know that whoever did this will be punished. If you can find them, I will take their names to the police.  I'll say my husband confessed on his death bed. I'll say I didn't have courage to come forward at first...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: It won't work like that.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Any evidence you collect can be given to the police later, anonymously.  I've thought about it and there's no other way.  If you can't find them... if the only thing that comes from this film is that this is all my husband will be remembered for, well I can't let that happen.  I'm telling you I won't.  If there's no chance that poor girl's memory can be served, then I'll just have to spend my last days trying to forget her.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I deal in divorce cases.  Corporate investigations...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: You've found missing persons before.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Nothing remotely like this.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: I know what I'm asking.  Your compensation will be appropriate to the risk.  You'll need cash to buy information, and I'll provide it.  I feel responsible, Mr. Welles.  You saw what he did to her.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Okay...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: My husband never dealt with money personally, certainly not cash.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I'm not positive this means anything.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: The checks were for odd amounts...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: One was for two hundred thousand, one dollar and thirteen cents. Another was for three hundred thousand, six hundred fifty four dollars and seventy six cents...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Okay, I follow you so far...

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Totalled together, these five checks from five different accounts, they equal one million dollars.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You're joking.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: To the penny.  Exactly one million dollars in cash.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Hello... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I'm here.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Do you think the film could have cost that much?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: For a human life... murder on film, no statute of limitations.  Who knows?  It sure could have.  I'd like you to overnight me a copy of those checks, then put them in a safe deposit box.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Send it to me through the post office like we arranged.  No return address.  You dug this up all by yourself?

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: You told me to look, so I looked.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You're one hell of a detective, Mrs. Christian.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Hello?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Mrs. Christian, Tom Welles here.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: How are you?  Having any luck?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I don't know if luck's the word. Are you feeling alright?

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: I've been ordered into bed.  The doctor says I've gotten the flu, or some other wretched ailment.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I hope it's nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Nothing more than a bother.  Have you any news for me?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I've made progress.  I'm in Manhattan.  Once a few more pieces fall into place, I'll drive to you and give you an update.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: Fine...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I've got about five thousand left in cash, but I'll need another thirty, if you approve.

dialogue.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
dialogue.text: How will I get it to you?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: If you have a pencil and paper, I'll tell you how to send it.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Yes... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Hello, Mrs. Mathews, my name's Thomas Jones, I'm a state licensed investigator...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I've been hired as an independent contractor by the U.S. Resource Center for Missing Persons as part of an internal audit.  If you have any time over the next few days, I'd like to make an appointment to ask some questions about the disappearance of your daughter.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: I don't understand, who are... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, let me explain, the R.C.M.P. is a support organization and archive, not unlike the Center for Missing and Exploited Children in Washington.  I'm sure you've dealt with them before?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Yes, but...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: These volunteer organizations are sort of interconnected, functioning hand in hand with law enforcement. The R.C.M.P. brought me in to review their investigations...  ... fact-check their records, see if there's anything they missed, anything they should be doing different.  I'm here for a few days, before I head back up to Virginia. These reports go to the Justice Department eventually.  I spoke to your F.B.I. contact a few days ago, uh...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: What was the name... ? I've got it here somewhere...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Neil... Neil Cole.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Right, Agent Cole told me he'd call and let you know to expect me.  He didn't call?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Well, I'm following up on your daughter, Mary, height; five four, weight; hundred ten pounds, brown eyes, blonde hair.  Born April 24, 1976.  Missing June 11th, 1992.  A runaway, that's how she's listed. Is this information correct... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: It's very important you don't let this raise your expectations.  It's not going to effect any ongoing efforts.  All I'm saying is, please know, I'm not here to create any false hope.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: They hired you.  You're like, a private detective?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: That's exactly what I am.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: I didn't think there were private detectives anymore, except on TV.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You probably expect me to be wearing a trench coat and a hat.  Drinking whiskey, chasing women and getting beaten up by guys with broken noses. Want to know what it's really like? It's sitting in a car and staring at a hotel window for three days straight, pissing in a plastic bottle, pardon me, because some guy thinks his wife's cheating on him. Glamorous, huh?  And the guy who hired you, he has a hair-lip, dandruff and crooked teeth, and you could have told him the minute you laid eyes on him his wife's cheating, and you don't blame her.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: So, she didn't leave a note?  She never gave any indication where she might go, before she left?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: She just seemed... depressed... ?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: She didn't seem herself.  For months there never was any way to get her to talk about it.  One night we went to bed... the next morning she was gone.  She took some clothes.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: What was she running from?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: If there's anything you feel uncomfortable talking about, tell me, but I have to ask.  Your husband... he committed suicide?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: September 4th, 1993.  About a year after Mary disappeared.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: We were divorced by then.  Things fell apart... he was living with a friend...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Why do you think he did it?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: It got to be too much for him.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You have to forgive me, but in these circumstances... with your daughter...  Were there any indications of... any sort of abuse?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: There wasn't anything like that. The police and the FBI people asked, but there wasn't anything happened like that, never.  My husband... his heart broke when Mary left...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I didn't mean to...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: You try going through what we did. Bob couldn't take it, that's all. Christ, there's times when it still seems like I can't either.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I had to ask.  I apologize.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: No one knows what it's like.  You can't even imagine how much it hurts.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: People remember me from the news.  Can you drive me back now?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Of course.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I... I shouldn't take anymore of your time.  Maybe we can finish tomorrow.  I'll call tomorrow...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Doesn't make much sense, does it? When everything's happy, when life's fine and you have every reason to believe there's a God, you don't bother.  Then, something horrible happens... that's when you start praying all the time.  That's when you start going to church.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: We're all like that.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Are you religious?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: You should be.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I've got what I need for my report. There is... there is one thing that bothers me though.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: It's not really my place, but it's not easy for me to set aside the private detective part of me either. See, I know a little about missing persons.  When kids run, they almost always leave a note.  It's guilt. They want to say goodbye.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: There wasn't one.  The police looked.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Do you think the police did a good job?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I think so.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: It is possible... and I know this isn't something you want to hear. Your daughter may have tried to hide a note where she thought you would eventually find it, but where she knew your husband would never find it.  She might have wanted to tell you something...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: No.  You don't have any reason to think that...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: If the police focused their search in her room, her belongings, well that'd be only natural, but they may have been looking in the wrong place.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: How... how can you say that to me...?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Will you let me look?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: My husband never laid a hand on her. She would have told me... she would have told me...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You're probably right, and I probably won't find anything. I don't have a right to ask this, and you can kick me out of your house if you want, but this is my profession and there's a part of me that can't let it go.  Police are just as human as you or I.  They could have missed something.  They probably didn't.  Wouldn't you rather know?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You were right.  I didn't find anything.  I'm going to run and get something to eat. Are you hungry?

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: I think about it everyday.  But, every time the phone rings... every single time, I still think it's her.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: It's been six years.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: What am I supposed to do?  Forget her?  Time heals all wounds, right?  She's all I think about, and I've learned to live with that.  But, you want the truth... the real truth? If I had a choice... if I had to choose, between her being out there, living a good life and being happy, and me not knowing; never finding out what happened to her...  ... or her being dead and me knowing...  I'd choose to know.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Hello... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Mrs. Mathews?  It's Thomas.  Do you remember, I was there a few weeks ago... asking about your daughter...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: I remember.  You just left...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I have to tell you something.  It won't be easy for you to hear.  It's about your daughter... Mary Anne...  When I... when I was there with you, her diary, in your attic, in silverware.  If you read it, you'll know what I'm telling you is true...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: What are you talking about... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: She went to California, to Los Angeles... she wanted to start over. She wanted to be an actress...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: What... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Mrs. Mathews, your daughter is dead. She's dead.

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Who is this... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Someone... some men, they took your daughter and they drugged her, and they took her to a motel room... they did terrible things to her...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Who are you?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: They brought her into the room... one man, he put a knife to her throat and he raped her...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: No...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: He raped her and...and...and he murdered her...he cut her up with knifes...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: No... no... no...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: They killed her, and they took her out in the forest somewhere and they buried her...

dialogue.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
dialogue.text: Why... why are you doing this to me... ?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: They murdered her, Mrs. Mathews, I'm sorry.  It happened a month after she ran away.  She's been dead all this time...

dialogue.speaker: NUN
dialogue.text: Yes... I remember Mary

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: You... you do?  You're sure? Please, Sister, will you take another look, make sure...

dialogue.speaker: NUN
dialogue.text: Yes.  I remember her.

dialogue.speaker: NUN
dialogue.text: Do you know what happened to her?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I'm trying to find out.  She was a runaway.  I'm looking into it for her parents.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: What is this?

dialogue.speaker: NUN
dialogue.text: Those are her belongings.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Her belongings?

dialogue.speaker: NUN
dialogue.text: That's her suitcase.  I had forgotten it, till you showed me her picture.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Whatever possessed you to keep this all this time?

dialogue.speaker: NUN
dialogue.text: She was the kindest, sweetest girl you'd ever want to meet.  Oh, I adored her.  I supposed I always hoped she'd be back.  After a time, all I could do was pray she had moved on to better things.  Can you get this suitcase to her parents, if you think it's appropriate?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: I'll do what I can.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Your son-in-law dealt with the dry cleaning franchise during the day, saw that woman every night.  The specifics are in the report, and information about the woman.  It's unpleasant, I know.  I apologize...

dialogue.speaker: POLITICIAN
dialogue.text: None too discreet, is he?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: No, sir, he is not.

dialogue.speaker: POLITICIAN
dialogue.text: He's an imbecile.  I tried to warn my daughter, but what can you do?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: The um... you'll find my invoice in the envelope. If that's all...

dialogue.speaker: POLITICIAN
dialogue.text: Yes, Mister Welles, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Certainly, Senator.  If I can ever be of further assistance.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Okay, I'll take it all.

dialogue.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogue.text: Excellent.  we accept MasterCard and American Express.

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Cash.

dialogue.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogue.text: Alright.  May I have your phone number, area code first?

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: No, you may not.

dialogue.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogue.text: Okay.  Fine.

dialogue.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogue.text: I'm required by state law to inform you that, while it's perfectly legal for you to purchase these items, it is illegal for you to use them for any sort of...

dialogue.speaker: WELLES
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know the spiel.  If you could bag it, I'll be on my way, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogue.text: Certainly, sir.

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: Don't you think it kind of defeats the purpose?

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: The mirror.  You can't see yourself in it.

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: I don't want to.

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: Yeah.  She'd be half as strict as you.

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: But she wouldn't let Dad treat me like that.

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: Look, you gotta stand up for yourself. Learn to fight back.

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: Rick...I can't.

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: Never say can't.  Just do what I do.

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: Alice, you think you can leave?

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: What's wrong?

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: Kincaid and Joey died last night.

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: You alright?

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: Kristen...

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: I heard you screaming.  Was it a bad one?

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: It was bad.

dialogue.speaker: RICK
dialogue.text: Doesn't the dream master work for you anymore?

dialogue.speaker: ALICE
dialogue.text: I can't find him.
